type.name: section
type.title: Grant to spouse of a deceased public officer.
type.context: PUBLIC OFFICERS SPOUSES ACT under Grant to spouse of a deceased public officer. 3. Whenever a public officer dies the Minister may order his or her salary for one month from the date of his or her death to be paid to his or her spouse.
type.description: Whenever a public officer dies the Minister may order his or her salary for one month from the date of his or her death to be paid to his or her spouse.

type.name: section
type.title: Payment of salary accrued due.
type.context: PUBLIC OFFICERS SPOUSES ACT under Payment of salary accrued due. 4. Notwithstanding anything to  the  contrary  in any Act passed  before the commencement of this Act, on the death of a public officer to whom any sum not exceeding ten thousand dollars is due from the Government in respect of salary, probate or other proof of the title of the personal representative of the deceased may be dispensed with, and that sum may be paid or distributed to or among the persons appearing to the Minister to be beneficially entitled to the personal estate of the deceased, or to or among any one or more of those persons, or, in the case of the illegitimacy of the deceased officer or his or her children, to or among the persons the Minister thinks fit.

type.name: section
type.title: Minister’s decision final.
type.context: PUBLIC OFFICERS SPOUSES ACT under Ministers decision final. 5. The decision of the Minister on any question which arises as to the application of any section of this Act to anyone or as to the amount to be paid to him or her shall be final.
type.description: The decision of the Minister on any question which arises as to the application of any section of this Act to anyone or as to the amount to be paid to him or her shall be final.

type.name: section
type.title: When payee absent from Guyana.
type.context: PUBLIC OFFICERS SPOUSES ACT under When payee absent from Guyana. 6. Where it has been decided under this Act to pay a sum to anyone not residing in Guyana, the Accountant General may pay that sum to anyone there resident who represents himself as, and the Accountant General that he is, the agent of the person not so resident even though no strict legal proof of agency is produced.
